subject: Sexual Health
title: Body Odor and Sweat
description: A quick, practical guide to Body Odor and Sweat.

hook.text: Body odor does not exist in young children. It appears during puberty when new sweat glands activate.

buildup.text: Apocrine glands in armpits and groin become active during puberty, producing thicker, protein-rich sweat.

discovery.text: Bacteria on the skin break down apocrine sweat into smelly compounds. The sweat itself is actually odorless.

twist.text: Genetics influence body odor. A gene variant common in East Asia significantly reduces apocrine sweat odor.

climax.text: Understanding the science of body odor helps teens manage it with hygiene rather than feeling embarrassed.

punchline.text: New glands, new bacteria, new smell. All totally normal.
